title: Appeal a special educational needs (SEN) statement decision

body.content:
Appeal to the Special Educational Needs and Disability Tribunal if you disagree with a decision your local authority has made about your child's special educational needs (SEN) statement.

^ The process is different if you want to [appeal a decision about an educational, health and care (EHC) plan](/appeal-ehc-plan-decision) or if you're [in Wales.](http://sentw.gov.wales/sentw-guidance-forms/appeals-sentw/?lang=en) ^

##Who can appeal

You must have parental responsibility for the child, or be their foster parent or carer. They must be at least school age and under 20 years old.

You can appeal if you don't agree with the SEN statement your local authority has made, or if they: 

* refuse to reassess your child’s needs
* refuse to change the parts of the SEN statement which are about educational needs (parts 2, 3 and 4) 
* decide your child doesn't need an SEN statement any more

##Help you can get  

Discuss the problem with [your local authority](/find-your-local-council) before you appeal. If you can’t agree you can ask to talk to a mediation adviser. They'll bring you and your local authority together to try to work out a solution.

If you decide to appeal, check if you can [get legal aid.](/check-legal-aid)

You can also get free help and advice from: 

- the [Independent Parent Special Education Advice (IPSEA)](https://www.ipsea.org.uk/contact/advice-and-support) 
- your local Parent Partnership Service through the [Information, Advice and Support Services (IASS) Network](http://www.iassnetwork.org.uk/)

$C   
**Information, Advice and Support Services (IASS) Network**    
<nppn@ncb.org.uk>  
Telephone: 020 7843 6958  
[Find out about call charges](/call-charges)  
$C  

*[EHC]: education, health and care  
*[SEN]: special educational needs

Appeal to the Special Educational Needs and Disability Tribunal if you disagree with a decision your local authority has made about your child’s special educational needs (SEN) statement.

The process is different if you want to appeal a decision about an educational, health and care (EHC) plan or if you’re in Wales.

Who can appeal

You must have parental responsibility for the child, or be their foster parent or carer. They must be at least school age and under 20 years old.

You can appeal if you don’t agree with the SEN statement your local authority has made, or if they:

  • refuse to reassess your child’s needs
  • refuse to change the parts of the SEN statement which are about educational needs (parts 2, 3 and 4)
  • decide your child doesn’t need an SEN statement any more

Help you can get

Discuss the problem with your local authority before you appeal. If you can’t agree you can ask to talk to a mediation adviser. They’ll bring you and your local authority together to try to work out a solution.

If you decide to appeal, check if you can get legal aid.

You can also get free help and advice from:

  • the Independent Parent Special Education Advice (IPSEA)
  • your local Parent Partnership Service through the Information, Advice and Support Services (IASS) Network

Information, Advice and Support Services (IASS) Network nppn@ncb.org.uk
Telephone: 020 7843 6958
Find out about call charges

You must have parental responsibility for the child, or be their foster parent or carer. They must be at least school age and under 20 years old.

##How to appeal  

Download and fill in [form SEND1A.](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=4475)

Send your completed form to the tribunal - the address is on the form. 

^ The tribunal must receive your form within 2 months of the date on your decision letter. ^  

You can include details of up to 3 witnesses who you'd like to bring to the hearing.  

##Change or withdraw your appeal  

You can change your appeal or withdraw it before the hearing.   

Download and fill in:  

* [form SEND7](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=3044) to change your appeal, for example to ask for a different hearing date or add more witnesses
* [form SEND8](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=3045) to withdraw your appeal

You must have parental responsibility for the child, or be their foster parent or carer. They must be at least school age and under 20 years old.

How to appeal

Download and fill in form SEND1A.

Send your completed form to the tribunal - the address is on the form.

The tribunal must receive your form within 2 months of the date on your decision letter.

You can include details of up to 3 witnesses who you’d like to bring to the hearing.

Change or withdraw your appeal

You can change your appeal or withdraw it before the hearing.

Download and fill in:

  • form SEND7 to change your appeal, for example to ask for a different hearing date or add more witnesses
  • form SEND8 to withdraw your appeal

The tribunal will hold the hearing at a venue within 2 hours of your home. You don't have to go, but if you do you can ask questions and present the case yourself.

Fill in the [attendance form](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=4471) if you want to bring:

- someone to represent you
- someone to support you   
- witnesses 

You can [ask to have an interpreter](/get-interpreter-at-court-or-tribunal) at the hearing. They'll translate what happens but they can’t represent you or give you legal advice.

You might be asked questions by:

+ your legal representative (if you have one)
+ the local authority's representative
+ the tribunal

##Who'll be at the hearing

The hearing will usually be attended by:

- up to 3 tribunal members
- a clerk
- someone representing the local authority
- [witnesses](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetLeaflet.do?court_leaflets_id=2720)   

Both parents can attend.

##Claim expenses  

You might be able to [claim travel expenses](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetLeaflet.do?court_leaflets_id=2644)  for going to the hearing. 

Your witnesses might also be able to [claim expenses for travel and loss of earnings.](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=2891)

If you bring a friend or relative to the hearing, you might also be able to claim for their travel costs. You'll be sent a form to make the claim.

^You'll usually get the tribunal's decision within 10 working days of the hearing.^

The tribunal will hold the hearing at a venue within 2 hours of your home. You don’t have to go, but if you do you can ask questions and present the case yourself.

Fill in the attendance form if you want to bring:

  • someone to represent you
  • someone to support you
  • witnesses

You can ask to have an interpreter at the hearing. They’ll translate what happens but they can’t represent you or give you legal advice.

You might be asked questions by:

  • your legal representative (if you have one)
  • the local authority’s representative
  • the tribunal

Who’ll be at the hearing

The hearing will usually be attended by:

  • up to 3 tribunal members
  • a clerk
  • someone representing the local authority
  • witnesses

Both parents can attend.

Claim expenses

You might be able to claim travel expenses for going to the hearing.

Your witnesses might also be able to claim expenses for travel and loss of earnings.

If you bring a friend or relative to the hearing, you might also be able to claim for their travel costs. You’ll be sent a form to make the claim.

You’ll usually get the tribunal’s decision within 10 working days of the hearing.

If you win your appeal, the local authority must act on the tribunal's decision within a set amount of time.

| Decision | When local authority must act |
| - | - |
| Start reassessment | Within 4 weeks |
| Change the needs or provision (parts 2 or 3) of the statement | Within 5 weeks |
| Change the school or placement (part 4) of the statement | Within 2 weeks |
| Continue with a statement | Immediately |
| Cancel ('cease to maintain') a statement | Immediately |

You can complain to the Local Government Ombudsman if the local authority doesn't act within the time allowed.  

$C **Local Government Ombudsman**  
[Enquiry form](http://www.lgo.org.uk/forms/ShowForm.asp?fm_fid=62)  
Telephone: 0300 061 0614  
[Find out about call charges](/call-charges) $C    

$A Local Government Ombudsman    

PO Box 4771  
Coventry  
CV4 0EH $A

If you win your appeal, the local authority must act on the tribunal’s decision within a set amount of time.

Decision When local authority must act
Start reassessment Within 4 weeks
Change the needs or provision (parts 2 or 3) of the statement Within 5 weeks
Change the school or placement (part 4) of the statement Within 2 weeks
Continue with a statement Immediately
Cancel (‘cease to maintain’) a statement Immediately

You can complain to the Local Government Ombudsman if the local authority doesn’t act within the time allowed.

Local Government Ombudsman
Enquiry form
Telephone: 0300 061 0614
Find out about call charges

Local Government Ombudsman
PO Box 4771
Coventry
CV4 0EH

You might be able to: - get the decision cancelled ('set aside') if you think there's been a mistake in the process - ask the tribunal to 'review' the decision, for example if your circumstances have changed since you got the decision or the decision contains a mistake - ask for permission to appeal to the Upper Tribunal (Administrative Appeals) Chamber if you think the tribunal's made a mistake in applying the law Your decision letter will tell you how to get the decision set aside or ask the tribunal to review the decision. ##Appeal to the Upper Tribunal You must [ask for permission to appeal](http://hmctsformfinder.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=2767) within 28 days of the date of the tribunal's decision letter. Contact the Special Educational Needs and Disability Tribunal if you have any questions about completing the form. The tribunal can’t give you legal advice. $C **Special Educational Needs and Disability Tribunal**
Telephone: 01325 289 350 Fax: 0870 739 4017 [Find out about call charges](/call-charges) $C

You might be able to:

  • get the decision cancelled (‘set aside’) if you think there’s been a mistake in the process
  • ask the tribunal to ‘review’ the decision, for example if your circumstances have changed since you got the decision or the decision contains a mistake
  • ask for permission to appeal to the Upper Tribunal (Administrative Appeals) Chamber if you think the tribunal’s made a mistake in applying the law

Your decision letter will tell you how to get the decision set aside or ask the tribunal to review the decision.

Appeal to the Upper Tribunal

You must ask for permission to appeal within 28 days of the date of the tribunal’s decision letter.

Contact the Special Educational Needs and Disability Tribunal if you have any questions about completing the form. The tribunal can’t give you legal advice.

Special Educational Needs and Disability Tribunal
send@hmcts.gsi.gov.uk
Telephone: 01325 289 350
Fax: 0870 739 4017
Find out about call charges

The tribunal will make a decision based on:

+ [Special Educational Needs and Disability Act 2001, Chapter 10](http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2001/10/contents)
+ [Education Act 1996](http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1996/56/contents)
+ [Code of Practice for Special Educational Needs 2001](/government/publications/special-educational-needs-sen-code-of-practice)
+ [Education (Special Educational Needs)(England)(Consolidation) Regulations 2001](http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2001/3455/contents/made)
+ [Tribunal Procedure (First–tier Tribunal) (Health, Education and Social Care Chambers) Rules 2008](http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2008/2699/made)

The tribunal will also use the practice directions for [First Tier and Upper Tribunal Child, Vulnerable Adult and Sensitive Witnesses.](http://www.justice.gov.uk/downloads/tribunals/special-educational-needs-and-disability/Childvulnerableadultandsensitivewitnesses.pdf)

The tribunal will make a decision based on:

  • Special Educational Needs and Disability Act 2001, Chapter 10
  • Education Act 1996
  • Code of Practice for Special Educational Needs 2001
  • Education (Special Educational Needs)(England)(Consolidation) Regulations 2001
  • Tribunal Procedure (First–tier Tribunal) (Health, Education and Social Care Chambers) Rules 2008

The tribunal will also use the practice directions for First Tier and Upper Tribunal Child, Vulnerable Adult and Sensitive Witnesses.
